title: 107_s1625
content: The Children's Health Equity Act of 2001 may approve up to 4 state waivers to use Title XXI allotments for increasing Medicaid children's enrollment. The definitions in this section include terms such as "child," "child health assistance," "enhanced FMAP," "Federal medical assistance percentage," "poverty line," "Secretary," and "State child health plan." The Secretary of Health and Human Services approves up to 4 waiver applications for states meeting specific requirements related to SCHIP income eligibility standards. The state must have the highest income eligibility standard allowed under title XXI of the Social Security Act as of January 1, 2001, and not limit applications for children. The state must have the highest income eligibility standard under title XXI of the Social Security Act as of January 1, 2001, and not limit applications for children. Children with family income at or below 200 percent of the poverty line should not face any waiting list or limitation for child health assistance. Additionally, the state must implement at least 4 policies related to coverage of children under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act. The State must implement at least 4 policies related to coverage of children under titles XIX and XXI of the Social Security Act, including using a uniform application form, eliminating asset tests for children, and adopting 12-month continuous enrollment. The State must adopt 12-month continuous enrollment and same verification policies for children eligible for medical assistance under title XXI of the Social Security Act. The State must ensure that initial eligibility determinations and redeterminations for children's medical assistance under titles XIX and XXI follow the same verification policies and procedures as outlined in title XXI of the Social Security Act. Additionally, enrollment staff must be stationed at designated healthcare facilities for processing applications. The State must ensure that children under title XIX receive care at designated facilities, including disproportionate share hospitals and Federally-qualified health centers. The Secretary will authorize payments to States with approved waivers under specific conditions, from their allotment under the Social Security Act. The Secretary will pay the State from its allotment under the Social Security Act an amount for each fiscal year, based on expenditures for medical assistance for children. The total expenditures for the fiscal year will be compared to the base expenditure amount for fiscal year 1995 to determine any increased expenditures. The Secretary determines increased expenditures for children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The bonus amount is calculated based on the difference between the enhanced FMAP and the Federal medical assistance percentage for the State. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act are described as those enrolled in the program and those with family income exceeding the eligibility level but considered disabled under specific criteria. Children eligible for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act are described as those enrolled in the program and those with family income exceeding the eligibility level but considered disabled under specific criteria. Payments to the State under section 2105(a) of the Social Security Act for a fiscal year with a waiver approved under this section shall be made in a specific order. Payments under section 2105(a) of the Social Security Act for a fiscal year with a waiver approved shall be made in a specific order: (A) for items in paragraph (1)(A), (B) for items in paragraph (1)(B), (C) for authorized payments under subsection (d)(1), (D) for items in paragraph (1)(C), and (E) for items in paragraph (1)(D).
